stems: put (someone or something) to the test

def: {bc} a set of questions or problems that are designed to measure a person's knowledge, skills, or abilities
{bc} a careful study of a part of the body or of a substance taken from the body
{bc} a careful study of a small amount of water, soil, air, etc., in order to see if its quality is good, to find out if it contains a dangerous substance, etc.

dt: {bc}a set of questions or problems that are designed to measure a person's knowledge, skills, or abilities

dt.t: She is studying for her math/spelling/history {it}test{/it}.
I passed/failed/flunked my biology {it}test{/it}.
The teacher sat at his desk grading {it}tests{/it}.
a driver's/driving {it}test{/it} [=a test that is used to see if someone is able to safely drive a car]
an IQ {it}test{/it}
{it}test{/it} questions
The {it}test{/it} will be on [=the questions on the test will be about] the first three chapters of the book.
We {phrase}took/had a test{/phrase} on European capitals. = ({it}Brit{/it}) We {phrase}did a test{/phrase} on European capitals.
The college relies on {phrase}test scores{/phrase} in its admissions process.

dt: {bc}a careful study of a part of the body or of a substance taken from the body

dt.t: The {it}test{/it} showed/revealed a problem with your liver function.
a vision/hearing {it}test{/it} [=a test that shows how well you see/hear]
a urine {it}test{/it} [=a test that examines a person's urine for evidence of disease or illegal drugs]
allergy {it}tests{/it} [=tests that show what you are allergic to]
All applicants must pass a {phrase}drug test{/phrase}. [=a test that examines a person's blood or urine for evidence of illegal drugs]
The doctor will call you with the {phrase}test results{/phrase}.
They went to the drug store to buy a {phrase}pregnancy test{/phrase}. [=a device that reacts to a woman's urine in a way that shows whether or not she is pregnant]
a {phrase}DNA test{/phrase} [=a test that examines DNA and that is used to identify someone or to show that people are relatives]

dt: {bc}a careful study of a small amount of water, soil, air, etc., in order to see if its quality is good, to find out if it contains a dangerous substance, etc.

dt.t: The {it}test{/it} indicated high levels of lead in the soil.
routine water {it}tests{/it}

dt: {bc}a planned and usually controlled act or series of acts that is done to learn something, to see if something works properly, etc.

dt.t: lab/laboratory {it}tests{/it}
underground nuclear {it}tests{/it}
a {it}test{/it} of a new vaccine
{phrase}Taste tests{/phrase} revealed that people prefer this brand of cola over that one.
As participants in the sleep study, {phrase}test subjects{/phrase} will be kept awake for 18 hours.
The effects of the drug were clear when the {phrase}test group{/phrase} was compared with the control group.

dt: {bc}something (such as a difficult situation or task) that shows how strong or skilled someone or something is

dt.t: a {it}test{/it} of will/strength/character
The real/true {it}test{/it} of your ability as a skier is whether you can ski well on very hard snow.

dros.drp: put (someone or something) to the test

dt: {bc}to cause (someone or something) to be in a situation that shows how strong, good, etc., that person or thing really is

dt.t: The team has been playing well so far, but tomorrow's game will really {it}put them to the test{/it}. [=will really test them]
A trip through the desert will {it}put{/it} the truck {it}to the test{/it}.
We decided to {it}put{/it} the idea/theory {it}to the test{/it} [=to test the theory] with a little experiment.

dt: {bc}to continue to be important, respected, etc., for a long period of time

dt.t: Great art/literature/music can {it}stand the test of time{/it}.

shortdef: a set of questions or problems that are designed to measure a person's knowledge, skills, or abilities
a careful study of a part of the body or of a substance taken from the body
a careful study of a small amount of water, soil, air, etc., in order to see if its quality is good, to find out if it contains a dangerous substance, etc.

stems: a picture is worth a thousand words
take the words right out of someone's mouth
take the words right out of someones mouth
in every sense of the word
have a word in your ear

def: {bc} a sound or combination of sounds that has a meaning and is spoken or written
{bc} a brief remark or conversation {bc} something that a person says

dt: {bc}a sound or combination of sounds that has a meaning and is spoken or written

dt.t: How do you spell that {it}word{/it}?
{ldquo}Please{rdquo} is a useful {it}word{/it}.
Our teacher often used {it}words{/it} I didn't know.
What is the French {it}word{/it} for car?
She was a genius {phrase}in every sense of the word{/phrase}. [=she was truly a genius]
You don't need to use {phrase}big words{/phrase} [=difficult words used to try to impress people] to make your point.
{phrase}Words fail me{/phrase}. [=I don't know what to say]

dt: {bc}a brief remark or conversation {bc}something that a person says

dt.t: You can't believe a {it}word{/it} (of what) she says. [=you can't believe anything she says]
Describe the experience in your own {it}words{/it}.
The lawyer used Joe's {it}words{/it} against him.
Could I {phrase}have a word with you{/phrase}? [=could I talk with you briefly?]
They gave me a {phrase}word of warning{/phrase} [=they told me about] about the slippery roads.
{phrase}Don't say/breathe a word{/phrase} [=don't talk] about this to anyone.
My grandfather was a {phrase}man of few words{/phrase}. [=a man who did not talk very much]
I've been asked to {phrase}say a few words{/phrase} [=make a short speech or statement] about the new play.
She gave the {it}word{/it} to begin.
We will wait for your {it}word{/it} before we serve dinner.
(Is there) Any {it}word{/it} on how they are?
If {it}word{/it} of this gets out, we're all in trouble.
What's the {it}word{/it}?
There is still no {it}word{/it} from the hospital.
{phrase}Spread the word{/phrase} [=tell the others] that we're leaving in five minutes.
They {phrase}sent word{/phrase} [=sent a message] that they'd be late.
{phrase}Word has it{/phrase} [=I have heard] that the neighbors are moving next month.
The police {phrase}put/got the word out{/phrase} that they were looking for him. [=the police let people know that they were looking for him]
I'll be there. I {phrase}give you my word{/phrase}. [=I promise]
You'd better {phrase}keep your word{/phrase}. [=keep your promise to do something]
He is a {phrase}man of his word{/phrase}. = {phrase}His word is his bond{/phrase}. [=he always keeps his promises]
I told her I'd help. I can't {phrase}go back on my word{/phrase}. [=I can't break my promise]
You'll have to {phrase}take my word for it{/phrase}. [=you'll have to believe me]
She was {phrase}true to her word{/phrase}. [=she did what she said she would do]
{it}Words{/it} were exchanged [=people said angry things to each other] and a fight broke out.
He {phrase}had words{/phrase} [=had an argument] with his boss.
{it}the Word{/it} of God

dros.drp: a picture is worth a thousand words

dt: {bc}a remark that is made privately to someone

dt.t: May I {phrase}have a word in your ear{/phrase} [=may I speak to you privately] before you leave?

dt: used to say that you are about to give someone advice or a warning

dt.t: {it}A word to the wise{/it}: never sign a contract without reading it first.
We found this hotel {it}by word of mouth{/it}.
The show was a success {it}from the word go{/it}.
We were in trouble ({it}right{/it}) {it}from the word go{/it}.
Please put in a {it}good word{/it} for me [=say something good about me] when you talk to the boss.
({it}US, informal{/it}) I haven't seen you in ages! {phrase}What's the good word{/phrase}? [={it}how's it going?; how are you?{/it}]

dt: used to indicate that you are saying something by using only one word or by using as few words as possible

dt.t: Our answer, {it}in a word{/it}, is no.

dt: used to introduce a statement that repeats what has been said in a different and usually a simpler or more exact way

dt.t: {ldquo}She said the movie was a bit predictable.{rdquo} {ldquo}{it}In other words{/it}, she didn't like it.{rdquo}
So, {it}in other words{/it}, you're saying that you forgot to do it.

dt: {bc}in exactly those words or in exactly that way

dt.t: {ldquo}Did he say he wouldn't do it?{rdquo} {ldquo}{phrase}Not in so many words{/phrase}, but that was the impression I got.{rdquo}
We explained our views to the press {it}in words of one syllable{/it}.

dt: {bc}to suggest that someone said or meant something that he or she did not say or mean

dt.t: Don't {it}put words in my mouth{/it}. I wasn't defending his actions, despite what you may think.
When you want to leave (just) {it}say the word{/it}.

dros.drp: take the words right out of someone's mouth

dt: {bc}to say exactly what someone was thinking

dt.t: I agree! You {it}took the words right out of my mouth{/it}!

dt: {bc}the final thing said in an argument or a discussion

dt.t: Your mother's decision is {it}the final word{/it} on the matter.
Why do you always have to {phrase}have the last word{/phrase}? [=to be the last person to speak]

dt: {bc}the power to make a final decision

dt.t: The judge will have {it}the last word{/it} [={it}the final say{/it}] on the divorce agreement.

dt: {bc}the most modern or best one of its kind

dt.t: This is {it}the last word{/it} in wireless phones.
The van's design is {it}the last word{/it} in safety.
{it}My word{/it}, what a beautiful dress!

dt: {bc}an argument in which people or groups criticize and disagree with each other publicly and repeatedly for usually a long time

dt.t: Rival groups have engaged in a {it}war of words{/it} over the new law.
He gave the same speech {it}word for word{/it} [={it}verbatim{/it}] yesterday.

dt: Your {it}word of honor{/it} is your promise that you will do something, that something is true, etc.

dt.t: I give you my {it}word of honor{/it} that I will pay the money back.

shortdef: a sound or combination of sounds that has a meaning and is spoken or written
a brief remark or conversation : something that a person says

def: {bc} to save (someone or something) from danger or harm

dt: {bc}to save (someone or something) from danger or harm

dt.t: The survivors were {it}rescued{/it} by the Coast Guard.
A fireman {it}rescued{/it} three children {it}from{/it} the burning building.
She {it}rescued{/it} an old chair {it}from{/it} the trash.

utxt.t: {it}Rescuers{/it} struggled to free the young man from the car wreck.

shortdef: to save (someone or something) from danger or harm —often + from —sometimes used figuratively

def: {bc} to change some parts of (something) while not changing other parts
{it}grammar{/it} {bc} to limit or describe the meaning of (a word or group of words)

dt: {bc}to change some parts of (something) while not changing other parts

dt.t: We can help you {it}modify{/it} an existing home or build a new one.
He {it}modified{/it} the recipe by using oil instead of butter.
{it}modify{/it} a plan
She has {it}modified{/it} her views on the matter.
The design was {it}modified{/it} to add another window.
We played a {it}modified{/it} version of our favorite game.

dt: {bc}to limit or describe the meaning of (a word or group of words)

dt.t: Adjectives usually {it}modify{/it} nouns, and adverbs usually {it}modify{/it} verbs, adjectives, and other adverbs.
In the phrase {ldquo}a red hat,{rdquo} the adjective {ldquo}red{rdquo} {it}modifies{/it} the noun {ldquo}hat.{rdquo}

shortdef: to change some parts of (something) while not changing other parts
to limit or describe the meaning of (a word or group of words)

dt.t: {it}modify{/it} a plan

dt: {bc}to lower or reduce in amount or degree {bc}{sx|moderate||}

dt.t: in the phrase {ldquo}green gloves,{rdquo} {ldquo}green{rdquo} {it}modifies{/it} {ldquo}gloves{rdquo}

shortdef: to lower or reduce in amount or degree : moderate

def: {bc} to accept or bear (someone or something bad, unpleasant, etc.)

dt: {bc}to accept or bear (someone or something bad, unpleasant, etc.)

dt.t: I can't {it}abide{/it} his bad moods. [=(more commonly) I can't stand his bad moods; I hate his bad moods]
{it}abide{/it} in the house of the Lord
a love that {it}abided{/it} till the end of their lives
We have to {it}abide by{/it} the rules.
They promise to {it}abide by{/it} our decision.

shortdef: to accept or bear (someone or something bad, unpleasant, etc.)—usually used in negative constructions
